tossups.question: Unlike his students, this man believed the influence of language on thought to be “of minor importance only.” Due to his tone deafness, this researcher had difficulty studying a tonal language in Laguna, New Mexico. This man, who studied physics and geography in graduate school in Germany, became interested in his most well-known field of influence after taking an expedition to northern (*) Canada, where he encountered and became fascinated with the Inuit culture on Baffin Island. This anthropologist spoke out against the ideology of scientific racism and introduced cultural relativism as an alternative. For 10 points, name this Columbia professor who created a four field subdivision of anthropology and taught Edward Sapir, Ruth Benedict, and Margaret Mead.

One character in this play says that “there’s small choice in rotten apples” when responding to another character’s complaints about a woman’s volatile nature. In one act in this play, one character disagrees with everything another character says, eventually getting her to say that the sun is the moon. In this play’s (*) Induction, this play is framed as being performed for the drunkard Christopher Sly, who is tricked into thinking he is a lord. A character in this play says that he has “come to wive it wealthy in Padua” and subsequently attempts to court the eldest daughter of Baptista, who is prohibited to marry before her younger sister, Bianca. For 10 points, name this Shakespearean comedy in which Petruchio attempts to perform the title action on Katharina.

In Ezra 10, priests who had married foreign women are condemned in a passage of this type. According to the documentary hypothesis, throughout the Pentateuch this literary style is used along with ritual narrative by a unique author whose work is known as the (*) Priestly source. In the New Testament, only two substantial passages of this type exist, and the differences of those passages in their respective gospels may be due to the recognition of levirate marriages mandated by Deuteronomy 25. For 10 points, name this type of passage which appears in Matthew and Luke describing Jesus and which appears in Genesis 10 for Noah under the title “Table of Nations,” a record of family lineages.

This technique was demonstrated in the 1910s and 1920s by the Kuleshov Effect, in which this technique caused an expressionless face to appear hungry, mournful, or lustful. Types of this technique include the “intellectual” and the “rhythmic,” the latter of which is exemplified by the (*) Odessa steps sequence of Battleship Potemkin by Sergei Eisenstein, a pioneer of the “Soviet theory” of this technique. A common use of this technique originating in American cinema sees an individual engaging in physical training through a series of short, cut sequences and overlaid with an inspirational, upbeat song. For 10 points, identify this film technique used in Rocky in which short shots are edited to condense space, time, and information.

James Killian advised the speaker of this speech to remove the word “scientific” from one phrase in this speech, which was mainly written by the then-president of the University of Minnesota, Malcolm Moos. This speech states how we “must avoid the impulse to live only for today” and that previously, “American makers of plowshares could, with time and as required, make (*) swords as well” in regarding the advent of its main topic. The speaker of this speech referred to its most enduring idea as a “potential enemy of the national interest” and “nothing more than a distorted use of the nation's resources.” For 10 points, name this final speech given in 1961 by the 34th President of the United States that warned against the dangers of the “military-industrial complex.”
tossups.answer: Eisenhower’s Farewell Address [accept Ike’s Farewell Address and reasonable equivalents] <Jin>

tossups.question: This astronomical body’s northern polar region is dominated by the presence of a dark-reddish area believed to be created from the buildup of residual tholins and is dubbed “Mordor.” A large, smooth plain on this body with no craters is known as Vulcan Planum, and the only flyby of this body discovered an ice mountain inside of a moat. This body was discovered by (*) James Christy in 1978 after observing a bulge in another body discovered by Clyde Tombaugh, and unlike most planet-moon systems, the center of mass of that two-body system is not inside of the parent body. For 10 points, name this satellite which was observed in 2015 by the spacecraft New Horizons, the largest moon of Pluto.

This author wrote a work in which the Pupil develops a toothache and eventually is stabbed to death by the Professor before a new Pupil enters. In addition to The Lesson, this writer used the common theme of a “radiant city” to depict a transcendental other world in such works as The Killer. This playwright produced a cycle of four plays which all include an (*) everyman who is over four hundred years old in Exit the King and who cries, “I’m not capitulating!” at the end of this writer’s most famous play; that character is Berenger. For 10 points, identify this playwright who wrote about the Fire Chief’s conversations with two families in The Bald Soprano and about Daisy succumbing to growing a horn in Rhinoceros, a French absurdist from Romania.

8. While still a teenager, this man fought in the War of the Second Coalition where he was held prisoner by the British after his ship was captured. Later, he fought in the Peninsular War, where he was awarded a gold medal and a promotion for his actions at the Battle of Bailén. In the Yatasto Relay, command over Army of the North was transferred from Manuel Belgrano to this man. In 1817, this man allied with (*) Bernardo O’Higgins and led an army across the Andes, subsequently winning the Battles of Maipu and Chacabuco to secure Chilean independence. For 10 points, name this Argentine general who met with Simon Bolivar at the Guayaquil Conference and liberated many South American countries from Spanish rule.
tossups.answer: José de San Martín y Matorras <Jin>

tossups.question: The development of this organ originates from the chorion frondosum and the decidua basalis. The microbiome of this organ conveys bacterial immunity for the first months of life when infection is most likely. Unequal sharing of this organ among identical twins, despite having two separate umbilical cords, may result in non-genetic developmental variety. The only (*) transient organ in the human body, the removal of this organ usually marks the end of the third period of childbirth. For 10 points, name this fetomaternal organ, which transfers blood and nutrition from mother to fetus.

During this event, communities near Jackson Hole, Wyoming reported many occurrences of illegal camping, while the state itself estimated a tripling of Wyoming’s population due to visitors for this event. In July 2017, Amazon required that all vendors selling (*) protective equipment for this event must have ISO accreditation for UV light. At a viewing party for this event, President Trump was rumored to have observed this event without proper protection. Renewable energy production in the line of totality was reduced during, for 10 points, what August 21, 2017 event in which the Sun was fully blocked by the Moon.
tossups.answer: total solar eclipse of 2017 [accept similar and prompt gratuitously; prompt on the Great American Eclipse] <Halza>

tossups.question: This Italian painter was a student of Filippo Lippi. Among his key early paintings are The Adoration of the Magi and portrayals of (*) Saints Sebastian and Augustine. For the Sistine Chapel, he painted the “Youth of Moses.” Returning from Rome to his native Florence, he painted two versions of The Annunciation and of the Lamentation over the Dead Christ. Among his many Madonna-with-Child paintings are ones subtitled Magnificat, Pomegranate, and Book. In this artist’s most famous painting, flowers float around the title figure in a shell. For 10 points, name this painter of Venus and Mars, The Spring, and The Birth of Venus.

Walter Leslie took an oath of loyalty to one notable figure in this conflict before assassinating him shortly afterwards. That figure was one of the leaders who signed the Treaty of Lubeck, which ended one country’s involvement in this conflict. The reign of a notable leader in this conflict nicknamed “the (*) winter king” was ended at the Battle of White Mountain. Another notable leader in this conflict died at the Battle of Lutzen; that leader is best known for his defeat of Count of Tilly at the Battle of Breitenfeld. For 10 points, name this seventeenth century war that began with the Second Defenestration of Prague and ended in 1648 with the Treaty of Westphalia.

In 1838, Charles Darwin expressed his support for a theory regarding the “theological state of thought” in this school of thought. This philosophy’s founder proposed that the first science to develop in society is mathematics and called sociology the “queen science.” That man also created what he called “a breach of continuity” by proposing the use of a (*) calendar with 13 months named after famous figures in European academia. This philosophical theory posits that society develops through stages known as theocratic, metaphysical, and one that names the theory. For 10 points, name this philosophy stating that knowledge is solely gained by sensing and interpreting natural phenomena, that was founded by Auguste Comte.
tossups.answer: positivism [or positive philosophy; accept Comtism before Comte is mentioned] <Jin>

tossups.question: In this composer’s only work for violin-piano duet, titled Things Seen Right-to-Left (Without Glasses), the composer writes, “My chorales equal those of Bach, with this difference: there are not so many of them, and they are less pretentious.” This composer wrote a piece inspired by the windows of the Notre Dame Cathedral that had (*) no bar-lines, and another piece by him begins with slow, alternating G-major-seventh and D-major-seventh chords in 3-4 time. In addition to Ogives [aw-ZHEEV], this composer’s Vexations consists of a series of enharmonic chords to be played 840 times. For 10 points, name this French composer of Desiccated Embryos, Three Pieces in the Form of a Pear, and a set of three Gymnopédies [zheem-noh-pay-dee].

In the last novel this author wrote before this author’s death, a white half-Jew enters into a controversial interracial marriage with a character who is recruited by the Movement and is called Jubu. In addition to No Time Like the Present, this author wrote about the physiotherapist Rosa who lives with her lover Bernard in Paris before being shamed by her childhood friend (*) Baasie to return to her home country in which her father Lionel was a political activist. This author also helped edit the speech, “I Am Prepared to Die” given by Nelson Mandela. For 10 points, identify this author of Burger’s Daughter who wrote about the Smales family’s struggles in post-apartheid South Africa in July’s People.

This figure corruptly removed half of the judges presiding over the court case Godden v. Hales to allow him to make exceptions to a law that had been enacted six years prior. This leader eased religious restrictions in the Declaration of Indulgence, which resulted in the overturning of a law that mandated heavy discrimination against Roman Catholics in public office positions called the (*) Test Act. Titus Oates created a fictitious plot claiming that Catholic conspirators were going to assassinate this leader’s predecessor in the Popish Plot. This leader was referred to in Ireland with a vulgar nickname after being defeated at and fleeing the Battle of the Boyne in 1690. For 10 points, name this last Stuart king who was overthrown by William and Mary in the Glorious Revolution.
tossups.answer: James II of England [or James VII of Scotland; prompt on James] <Jin>

tossups.question: One of this god’s epithets is Petraios, and this god granted Mestra the ability to metamorphose and escape the men to whom her father had married her off. In one story, this god raped a woman who ultimately was crushed all the way down to Tartarus with (*) fir trees and stones by a group of centaurs. Disguised as the river god Epineus, this god seduced Tyro, making him the father of Pelias and Neleus. Iphimedia tried daily to get this god to impregnate her, and eventually succeeded, resulting in the birth of the Aloadae, Otus and Ephialtes. For 10 points, name this god, who built the walls of Troy with Apollo, and who fathered Pegasus and Chrysaor when he raped Medusa in the temple of Athena.
tossups.answer: Poseidon [do not accept Neptune (all the clues are from Thessaly except the last which still isn’t Neptune)] <Yoshida>

tossups.question: The Eightfold Way was proposed independently by Yuval Ne'eman and Murray Gell-Mann to organize these things by their strangeness into octets and decuplets. Jets of this class of particles can be observed after collisions of high energy particles in a process known by their name followed by (*) “-ization,” since their constituents spontaneously combine due to color confinement. These composite particles are divided into two families based on whether they are composed of two or three valence quarks. The world’s most powerful particle collider is named after these things, since it collides the only stable, free type of them, the proton. For 10 points, give this name for the general class of particles that includes baryons and mesons and are tested at the LHC.
tossups.answer: hadrons [accept mesons before “decuplets,” anti-prompt on baryons, mesons, or quarks] <McMaken>

tossups.question: In a poem by this writer, characters create a tunnel and call it “Aladdin's wondrous cave." In another poem, this writer exclaims, “Behold! the drink of the gods," and, in alluding to Vedic religious practice, “bring honey from the hollow oak.” This writer criticized a political figure allowing the passing of a fugitive slave bill by stating “When faith is lost, when honor dies / The man is dead!" in the poem (*) “Ichabod.” In another poem by this writer of “Maud Muller,” a woman who was the bravest of “all in Frederick town” tells Confederate troops, “Shoot, if you must, this old gray head, but spare your country's flag.” For 10 points, name this Quaker poet of “Snow-Bound” and “Barbara Frietchie.”

This letter denotes a quantity which describes the compensation of the loss of chemical potential from the addition of a solute. That quantity denoted by this letter is computed as the product of the molar concentration, the ideal gas constant, the temperature, and the van ’t Hoff factor, and is known as the (*) osmotic pressure. According to Hückel’s Rule, aromatic molecules are characterized by 4n+2 electrons designated by this letter, and bonds designated by this letter occur when two lobes of an atomic orbital overlap with two lobes of another atomic orbital. For 10 points, identify this letter which denotes bonds that are weaker than sigma bonds and also denotes the ratio of a circle’s circumference to its diameter.

21. The capital of this European country hosted the World Chess Championship in 1972. One of the participants of that event was granted citizenship of this country in his final years. This country is also notable for its (*) volcanic eruptions, one of which severely disrupted air travel in Europe in 2010. People in this country receive patronymic last names, derived from their father’s first name plus the suffix -S-S-O-N.. This country won its independence from Denmark in the twentieth century. For 10 points, name this eighteenth-largest island in the world, with capital at Reykjavik.

bonuses.leadin: Herman Melville said that this work was as “deep as Dante,” and Henry James called it a “magnificent little romance.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this work which tells of a man’s loss of faith as he finds himself in the forest with his wife, Faith, and learns his entire Christian town is taking part in a witches sabbath.
Young Goodman Brown is a work by this author, who frequently wrote works that took place in the Salem Witch Trials. This author also wrote The House of the Seven Gables.
In this other Hawthorne work, Aylmer tries to perfect his wife’s body by removing the titular blemish, but ends up killing her instead.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about pyramids around the world, for 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: North Korea [or Democratic People’s Republic of Korea; prompt on Korea]
parts: The pyramidal Ryugyong Hotel in this country remains unfinished despite its construction starting in 1987. A grand opening was planned in 2012 on the centenary of this country’s “Eternal President” Kim Il-Sung, but it was eventually scrapped.

The Pyramid of the Sun at this famed Mesoamerican site is the third largest pyramid in the world. Home to the Avenue of the Dead and the Pyramid of the Moon, the mysterious inhabitants of this ancient city were also known for the export of obsidian.

The Great Pyramid of Giza is named for this Old Kingdom monarch. Although this son of King Sneferu created the largest of the Egyptian pyramids, the only artifact maintaining this king’s likeness is a small ivory statue.

bonuses.leadin: This technique marked the beginning of serialism in Western music in the twentieth century. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this technique pioneered by Arnold Schoenberg in which the namesake number of pitch classes are arranged in tone rows to give them all equal importance.
Though not retrograde, this interval-preserving transformation of a tone row turns it upside-down, since each rising interval is converted into its equivalent falling interval and vice versa.

This professor at Yale expanded on the structure of atonal music with his namesake numbers used to categorize every possible combination of notes into a series of pitch class sets. His name is also spelled the same as a certain dynamic marking.

bonuses.leadin: In this work, Sun Wukong urinates on five pillars before realizing they are actually the fingers of Buddha’s hand. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Journey to the West [or Xi You Ji]
Dream of the Red Chamber [or Hong Lou Meng, or The Story of the Stone] <McMaken>
parts: Name this 100 chapter novel in which the Monkey King accompanies a monk and a sand demon while traveling to Vulture Peak in India.

Journey to the West was written during this Chinese dynasty which was succeeded by the Qing dynasty and during which three of the Four Great Classical Novels were written, including Water Margin and Romance of the Three Kingdoms.
This last of China’s Four Great Classical Novels was produced during the Qing dynasty and follows two branches of the Jia family. In it, Jia Baoyu is born with a glowing piece of jade in his mouth.

bonuses.leadin: U.S. states have had their fair share of border disputes. For 10 points each:
parts: This 1835 to 1836 war, named after an Ohio city, saw the militias of Michigan and Ohio face off across the Maumee River. In exchange for the namesake city, this war was ended by ceding the Upper Peninsula to Michigan.

The 1839 Honey War, fought between Iowa and this state, sought to define the latitudinal border running along the Des Moines. Elsewhere, the land possessions of John Hardeman Walker would ultimately become this state’s southeastern “bootheel” in 1820.

This man set California’s eastern border to be along the crest of the Sierra Nevada without a survey, which would lead to the 1863 Sagebrush War between California and Nevada. He also served as the Republican Party’s first presidential candidate.

bonuses.leadin: This philosopher claimed that there could be a teapot orbiting the Sun somewhere between Earth and Mars. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Bertrand Arthur William Russell, 3rd Earl Russell
parts: Name this British logician who taught Ludwig Wittgenstein and is considered one of the founders of analytic philosophy.

In an attempt to create a complete logical basis for mathematics, Russell co-wrote this three-volume work along with A. N. Whitehead, though their attempts were proved to be futile when Gödel published his incompleteness theorem a few decades later.
Russell also wrote this essay in 1905 which discussed definite and indefinite descriptions, exemplified by the statement, “The present king of France is bald.”

bonuses.leadin: A yellow one of these objects from Celtic mythology inflicts wounds from which nobody can heal. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these weapons, a jeweled variety of which was used to create the Japanese islands.
This specific spear from Norse mythology can strike any target no matter the distance and ability of the thrower. It also has runes carved into its tip.
Gae Bulg is the spear of this “Hound of Ulster.” This hero was known to go into a battle frenzy in which he single-handedly took on entire armies.

bonuses.leadin: Compass and straightedge ready. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: squaring the circle [or quadrature of the circle] <McMaken>
parts: We won’t actually be using these tools, but mathematicians have spent a lot of time thinking about them, including this German who worked out in 1796 which polygons can be constructed from them. He also proved the fundamental theorem of algebra and found out how to add the numbers from 1 to 100 when he was eight years old.

For a line segment connecting points A and B, by drawing circles of equal radii centered at points A and B, one can construct this type of line that passes through the circles’ two intersections. In a triangle, three of these things meet at the circumcenter.

This task is impossible to carry out with just a straightedge and compass because the square root of pi is a transcendental number. This task involves constructing two certain shapes so that they have equal areas.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about foods named after famous people in history, for 10 points each:
parts: This puff pastry-wrapped tenderloin dish was named after Arthur Wellesley, a famed field marshal who defeated Napoleon Bonaparte at the Battle of Waterloo. The dish’s name derives from the Somerset town of which Wellesley was the first duke.

A false history attributes the creation of this classic Neapolitan pizza to Raffaele Esposito in homage to the namesake Queen of Italy in 1890. Tradition has it that the tomato, mozzarella, and basil on this pizza represent the colors of the Italian flag.

This baked meringue dessert derives its name from a world famous Russian ballerina in the early 1900s. Commonly topped with cream and fruit, this dessert is a common summer dish in Australia and New Zealand.

bonuses.leadin: This story’s ending can be seen as a reversal of the twist ending of “The Necklace.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Henri René Albert Guy de Maupassant
“Boule de Suif” [or “Ball of Fat” or “Dumpling” or “Butterball” or “Ball of Lard”] <Jin>
parts: Name this Henry James short story in which a string of pearls is eventually found to be genuine. In “The Necklace,” Madame Forestier tells Mathilde that the original necklace was “made of [this].”
“The Necklace” is a short story written by this French author who often wrote pessimistic stories set during the Franco-Prussian War.
Another of Maupassant’s most famous short stories is this work, in which the title character sleeps with a Prussian officer so that a carriage and its passengers can leave.

bonuses.leadin: Fleming’s version of this mnemonic can be used to find the direction of current in a generator. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this rule whose namesake object can be used to determine the chiral conventions for the direction of the cross product of two vectors in three dimensions.
If a negative charge is moving into the page within a magnetic field pointing South, then the corresponding Lorentz force on the negative particle points in this direction.

By choosing the thumb to point away from the Earth, the right-hand rule can also give the direction of rotation of low-pressure areas in the Northern Hemisphere due to this inertial effect, which causes the deflection of objects moving in a North-South trajectory by its namesake fictitious force.

bonuses.leadin: This island is the third largest on the Eastern Coast of the United States, after Long Island and Mount Desert Island. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Massachusetts island which comprises a majority of Dukes County and is situated northwest of Nantucket Island.

Martha’s Vineyard is located approximately 7 miles south of this narrow peninsula which is home to cities like Provincetown and Barnstable. This peninsula received its name from an abundant resource that supported the local maritime industry.

This smaller “island” is ironically connected to Martha’s Vineyard by a barrier beach known as Norton Point. An eponymous incident on this island saw then-Senator Ted Kennedy drive his car off of a bridge, fatally trapping his passenger Mary Jo Kopechne.

bonuses.leadin: In this painting, a young man hidden in some bushes gazes at a woman. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: The Happy Accidents of the Swing (or Les Hasards heureux de l’escarpolette)
parts: Identify this oil painting in which a woman kicks her shoe toward Cupid.
The Swing was painted by this French Rococo artist who also painted The Bathers, Blind Man’s Bluff, and The Stolen Kiss.
This other Rococo painter was an Englishman who painted landscapes such as Cornard Wood and portraits like The Blue Boy.

bonuses.leadin: This man payed money to the Danes after losing at the Battle of Maldon. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this English king who came to the throne as a tweenager and whose nickname is a pun meaning, “ill-advised.”
In 1002, Æthelred made an alliance with this territory by marrying the daughter of the Duke, Emma. Æthelred later fled to this territory after King Sweyn Forkbeard of Denmark invaded England.
After the death of Æthelred in April of 1016, this son of Æthelred became King of England for six months until his death, ruling Wessex even after Cnut the Great conquered England.

bonuses.leadin: This work’s setting was based on a short work by Christoph Wieland [VEE-landt]. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: The Abduction from the Seraglio [or Die Entfuhrung aus dem Serail or Il Seraglio]
parts: Name this opera which tells of Tamino’s quest to find Pamina. Famous numbers include the Queen of the Night’s “Der Holle Rache kocht in meinem Herzen,” and Sarastro’s “O Isis und Osiris.”
This singspiel opera in three acts features Belmonte’s attempts to rescue Konstanze from Pasha Selim. Emperor Joseph II supposedly commented “too many notes” after hearing this opera.
For the premier of The Magic Flute, this man sang the role of Papageno, though he is better known for being the librettist for that opera.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following questions about Hinduism, for 10 points each:
parts: This holiday includes bonfires on its eve to celebrate the burning of a demoness. People also apply colored powders to each other during this festival.

One legend surrounding the celebration of Holi concerns this god who became the avatar Narasimha to protect Prahlada by slaying Hiranyakashipu [hee-rahn-yah-KAH-shee-poo] in a “half-man, half-lion” form.

In the Sri Vaishnava lists, another one of Vishnu’s avatars is this brother of Krishna, who was born fair. However, he is generally thought to be an avatar of Seshat and also taught Pandava Bhima how to fight with a mace.

bonuses.leadin: This man, despite being a trained electrician, completed much of his early advocacy work in shipyards. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Polish labor activist who organized the first independent Warsaw Pact labor union at the Lenin Shipyard of Gdansk.

Walesa was the head of this labor union, which comprised a majority government in Poland’s first semi-free elections under Soviet overhead in 1989. As leader of this labor union, Walesa became president of Poland in that election.

In 2011, Walesa rejected the Order of Vytautas the Great, a presidential award bestowed on political leaders in service to this country. Poland and this country were unified in a commonwealth that lasted from the 16th century through the 18th century.

bonuses.leadin: The specific heat of a material can be calculated by taking the partial derivative of this quantity with respect to temperature under constant pressure. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity equal to Gibbs free energy plus the product of temperature and entropy and is notably a state function.

This type of thermodynamic process is used after the isothermal expansion and isothermal compression steps in the Carnot cycle. It asymptotically approaches the P and V axes when represented on a P-V diagram and occur without any transfer of heat.
This double-eponymous law states that molar heat capacity of many solid elements is about 3 times the universal gas constant, or about 25 joules per kelvin.

bonuses.leadin: This novel is known for having a relatively happy ending compared to its author’s other novels, despite its ambiguous ending. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Under the Greenwood Tree: A Rural Painting of the Dutch School
parts: Name this novel that details the romantic relationship between a young member of the Mellstock choir and the schoolmistress Fancy Day. Its title taken from Shakespeare’s As You Like It.

The aforementioned young choir member has this surname. His grandfather makes an appearance in another of the author’s novels where he allegedly causes a raging bull to lay down by playing it a Christmas hymn on a fiddle.
Under the Greenwood Tree was the second of this author’s “Wessex novels.” This author is also known for such other works as Far from the Madding Crowd and Tess of the d’Urbervilles.

bonuses.leadin: The plasma membrane is composed of many complex parts working in tandem. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: glycocalyx [also pericellular matrix] (prompt on extracellular matrix) <Halza>
parts: The primary component of the plasma membrane is this amphipathic molecule, composed of a hydrophilic head and two hydrophobic hydrocarbon tails. It forms a namesake bilayer in cell membranes.

This amphipathic modified steroid is also prevalent in the plasma membrane, providing more rigid structure to the fluid phospholipid bilayer. When in excess in humans, this molecule can build up in arteries and result in atherosclerosis.

Membrane lipids and proteins that are glycosylated upon inclusion in the membrane combine to form this carbohydrate surface coat. This extracellular layer is utilized in cell-to-cell recognition and intercellular adhesion.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following questions about a certain American author, for 10 points each:
parts: One of the first great American authors, this pioneer of detective fiction died of unknown causes, with suggested causes ranging from diabetes to murder. He wrote “Berenice” and “The Purloined Letter.”
This Poe short story features an unnamed narrator who claims to have been disturbed by an old man with a “vulture eye.”
This other Poe short story won first prize in a newspaper contest and also helped to popularize cryptograms as a literary device.
